Award.AwardTitle: Cosmic String Network Simulation and Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the cosmic-string research of Professors Ken Olum and Jose Blanco-Pillado at Tufs University.

Cosmic strings are microscopically thin or even fundamental objects of cosmological length. They can arise from symmetry breaking in field theory or from superstring theory. They can produce observational signatures in the cosmic microwave background, in cosmic rays, in ultra-high-energy neutrinos, or in gravity waves. If cosmic strings are detected, they will provide a window onto fundamental physics and energies beyond the reach of any accelerator. Over the past three years, the Tufts cosmology group has developed a large, parallel computer simulation of cosmic string networks. This simulation can handle a much larger volume for a much longer time than any other. This project will make use of this simulation in order to study the shapes of cosmic string loops, the power spectrum of excitations on long cosmic strings, and the the specific processes which give rise to the spectrum of cosmic string loops. All these questions are of paramount importance to the observational signatures of a string network.

The project will have a broader impact through the involvement of graduate students and through opportunities for students from underrepresented groups to participate in research. Its results will be broadly disseminated through publication in journals and made available to the public on the World Wide Web. This project will also benefit society by further connecting studies of the universe with studies of the fundamental laws of nature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cosmic strings are microscopically thin, astronomically long objects
that might exist in our universe.  They could arise from symmetry
breaking in grand unified field theories, or they could be the
fundamental strings of string theory stretched out to astronomical
size.  If cosmic strings exist, their discovery would give us valuable
information on high-energy physics and the fundamental laws of nature.

Cosmic strings, if they exist, form a "network" consisting of long
strings that wander over great distances (perhaps forever if the
universe is infinite) and smaller loops.  When two strings cross, they
may exchange partners, and if a string crosses itself the crossing may
produce a loop.  Loops of a wide range of sizes are continually being
produced from the long string network.  Once a loop is produced, it
oscillates periodically and emits gravitational waves.  Eventually the
loop loses all its energy into these gravitational waves and
disappears.

How can we know whether cosmic strings exist?  What signals would they
give off that that would tell us of their existence?  An attractive
possibility is the gravitational waves emitted by the loops.  These
waves might be detected, for example, by precision timing of signals
from pulsars.  Other possibilities include gamma rays,
ultra-high-energy cosmic rays, distortions of the cosmic microwave
background, and several others.

To look for cosmic strings, we have to know what to expect.  How many
loops would there be today and at each previous epoch in the history
of the universe?  What is the distribution of shapes of these loops?
This project sought to determine the answers to these questions and so
to enable us to calculate what observable signals might be expected.

How did we answer these questions?  First, we did a large-scale
computer simulation of networks of cosmic strings.  From the
simulation we determined the rate of production of loops of different
sizes.  Then we analyzed the effect of this loop production rate in a
cosmological context.  We considered the lifetime of loops and their
dilution due to the expansion of the universe.  We found that most
loops that exist at any given epoch are small ones (relative to the
size of the universe), which were produced much earlier and have lived
out a significant fraction of their lifetime.  We gave an accurate
statement of the density of loops for use in observational
calculations.  As an example, we calculated the gravitational
radiation that the loops would produce and set an upper bound on the
energy scale of cosmic strings based on the fact that such
gravitational radiation has not been observed.

Then we extracted many loops that were produced in our simulations and
considered their shapes.  We were surprised to find that these loops
were not at all smooth.  Instead, they were composed of several rather
straight segments connected by sharp bends (which are called "kinks").
This is very important to the generation of observational signals,
because many signals are generated by cusps, where the string bends
back on itself and moves nearly at the speed of light.  Nearly all
smooth strings have cusps, but strings with kinks typically do not
have cusps, so their observational signals are different.
